data.title: Variables
data.code:
let name = "Alice"; // Block-scoped, can be reassigned
const age = 30; // Block-scoped, cannot be reassigned
data.description: Use "let" for reassignable variables and "const" for constants.

data.title: Data Types
data.code:
let str = "Hello"; // Strings are text
let num = 42; // Numbers include integers and floats
let isTrue = true; // Booleans are true or false
let nothing = null; // Null represents intentional emptiness
let notDefined; // Undefined means a variable is declared but not assigned
let unique = Symbol("id"); // Symbols are unique identifiers
let big = 9007199254740991n; // BigInt is for numbers larger than Number can hold
let obj = { key: "value" }; // Objects store key-value pairs
data.description: JavaScript has 8 data types: String, Number, Boolean, Null, Undefined, Symbol, BigInt, and Object.

data.title: Type Coercion
data.code:
console.log(5 + "5"); // "55" (number + string)
console.log(5 - "3"); // 2 (string converted to number)
console.log("5" == 5); // true (loose equality converts types)
console.log("5" === 5); // false (strict equality checks type)
data.description: Loose equality ("==") converts types, while strict equality ("===") does not.

data.title: Type Conversion
data.code:
console.log(Number("42")); // 42
console.log(String(42)); // "42"
console.log(Boolean(1)); // true
console.log(parseInt("42px")); // 42
data.description: Use "Number()", "String()", and "Boolean()" for explicit type conversion.

data.title: Arithmetic Operators
data.description: Perform calculations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division.

data.title: Comparison Operators
data.code:
console.log(5 > 3);  // true
console.log(5 >= 3);  // true (greater than or equal to)
console.log(3 < 5);  // true
console.log(3 <= 5);  // true (less than or equal to)
console.log(5 === "5");  // false (strict equality, checks type too)
console.log(5 == "5");  // true (loose equality, converts type)
console.log(5 !== 3);  // true (not equal)
data.description: Used to compare values and check equality, inequality, and range.

data.title: Logical Operators
data.code:
console.log(5 > 3 && 8 > 4);  // true (AND)
console.log(5 > 3 || 2 > 4);  // true (OR)
console.log(!(5 > 3));  // false (NOT)
data.description: Used to combine multiple conditions.

data.title: Assignment Operators
data.code:
let x = 5;  // Assigns 5 to x
x = 10;  // Reassigns 10 to x (previous value is overwritten)
x += 3;  // Adds 3 to x (x = x + 3)
x -= 2;  // Subtracts 2 from x (x = x - 2)
x *= 4;  // Multiplies x by 4 (x = x * 4)
x /= 2;  // Divides x by 2 (x = x / 2)
x %= 3;  // Modulus: x = x % 3
x **= 2;  // Raises x to the power of 2 (x = x ** 2)
data.description: Used to assign values to variables, perform operations on them, and reassign values.

data.title: Conditional (Ternary) Operator
data.description: A shorthand for 'if-else' statements, used for conditional assignments.

data.title: Typeof Operator
data.description: Used to check the type of a variable or value.

data.title: Instanceof Operator
data.code:
const date = new Date();
console.log(date instanceof Date);  // Output: true
console.log(date instanceof Object);  // Output: true
console.log(date instanceof Array);  // Output: false
data.description: Checks whether an object is an instance of a specific class or constructor function.

data.title: Destructuring Assignment (Object)
data.description: Extracts values from objects and assigns them to variables.

data.title: Spread Operator
data.description: Allows iterables (like arrays or objects) to be expanded into individual elements.

data.title: Rest Parameters
data.description: Collects all remaining arguments into an array.

data.title: Default Parameters
data.description: Allows functions to have default values for parameters if no value is passed.

data.title: Template Literals
data.description: Provides a way to embed expressions inside string literals using `${ }`.

data.title: Destructuring Assignment (Array)
data.description: Extracts values from arrays and assigns them to variables.

data.title: Function Expressions
data.description: A function that is defined and assigned to a variable.

data.title: Arrow Functions
data.code:
const greet = (name) => `Hello, ${name}!`;
console.log(greet('Alice'));  // Output: 'Hello, Alice!'
data.description: A concise way to write functions with an implicit return.

data.title: For Loop
data.description: Repeats a block of code a set number of times based on a condition.

data.title: While Loop
data.description: Repeats a block of code as long as a specified condition is true.

data.title: forEach (Array Method)
data.code:
const arr = [1, 2, 3];
arr.forEach(num => console.log(num)); // Output: 1, 2, 3
data.description: Executes a provided function once for each array element.

data.title: Fetch Call (Async/Await with try/catch)
data.description: Fetch data from a URL with async/await syntax, handling errors using try/catch.

data.title: Fetch: GET
data.description: Retrieves data from a specified URL.

data.title: Fetch: POST
data.description: Sends data to the server, typically for creating or updating a resource.

data.title: Fetch: PUT
data.description: Replaces a resource with new data.

data.title: Fetch: DELETE
data.description: Deletes a resource at the specified URL.

data.title: Event Handling
data.description: Listens for and reacts to events.

data.title: querySelectors
data.code:
document.querySelector('.class-name'); // Selects by class
document.querySelector('#id-name'); // Selects by ID
document.querySelector('div'); // Selects by tag name
document.querySelector('[data-attribute]'); // Selects by attribute
data.description: Different ways to select elements from the DOM.

data.title: Array.prototype.map()
data.description: Creates a new array by applying a function to each element.

data.title: Array.prototype.filter()
data.description: Creates a new array with elements that pass a test.

data.title: Array.prototype.reduce()
data.description: Reduces the array to a single value using a function.

data.title: Array.find()
data.description: Returns the first element that satisfies the test.

data.title: Array.some()
data.description: Checks if at least one element passes the test.

data.title: Array.every()
data.description: Checks if all elements pass the test.

data.title: Array.push()
data.description: Adds one or more elements to the end of an array.

data.title: Array.pop()
data.description: Removes the last element from an array.

data.title: Array.shift()
data.description: Removes the first element from an array.

data.title: Array.unshift()
data.description: Adds one or more elements to the beginning of an array.

data.title: Array.splice()
data.description: Adds or removes elements at a specific index.

data.title: Array.reverse()
data.description: Reverses the order of the elements in an array.

data.title: Accessing Array by Index
data.description: Accesses an item from an array using its index.

data.title: Accessing Object Property
data.description: Accesses a property of an object using dot notation.

data.title: Accessing Nested Object Property
data.description: Accesses a nested property inside an object.

data.title: Accessing Array of Objects
data.description: Accesses a property of an object within an array.

data.title: Checking if an Array Includes a Value
data.code:
const arr = [1, 2, 3, 4];
console.log(arr.includes(2)); // Output: true
data.description: Checks if an array contains a value.

data.title: Promises & Chaining
data.code:
fetch("https://api.example.com/data")
  .then(response => response.json())
  .then(data => console.log(data))
  .catch(error => console.error(error));
data.description: Handles async operations with ".then()" chaining and ".catch()" for errors.

data.title: JavaScript Classes
data.description: Defines a class with a constructor and a method.

data.title: Class Inheritance
data.description: A class can inherit from another class and override methods.

data.title: testingTitle
data.code: testingCode
data.description: testingDescription
